variant.question: An aeroplane uses rudder aileron cross-coupling coupling to prevent adverse yaw. What happens if the aeroplane is rolled to the left?

options.text: The left aileron is deflected up, the right aileron is deflected down and the rudder is deflected to the left automatically.
The left aileron is deflected up, the right aileron is deflected down and the rudder is deflected to the right automatically.
The left aileron is deflected down, the right aileron is deflected up and the rudder is deflected to the right automatically.
The left aileron is deflected down, the right aileron is deflected up and the rudder is deflected to the left automatically.

variant.question: An aeroplane uses rudder aileron cross-coupling coupling to prevent adverse yaw. What happens if the aeroplane is rolled to the right?

options.text: The left aileron is deflected down, the right aileron is deflected up and the rudder is deflected to the right automatically.
The left aileron is deflected up, the right aileron is deflected down and the rudder is deflected to the left automatically.
The left aileron is deflected down, the right aileron is deflected up and the rudder is deflected to the left automatically.
The left aileron is deflected up, the right aileron is deflected down and the rudder is deflected to the right automatically.

variant.question: When an aircraft is rolled to the left, adverse yaw will be reduced by:

options.text: a Frise aileron being effective on the left wing.
Frise ailerons producing increased drag on both surfaces.
the leading edge of the down-going aileron protruding into the airflow.
the down-going aileron moving through a greater angle of deflection than the up-going aileron.

variant.question: One method to compensate adverse yaw is:

options.text: a differential aileron.
an anti-balance tab.
a balance panel.
a balance tab.

variant.question: When a turn is initiated, adverse yaw is

options.text: the tendency of an aeroplane to yaw in the opposite direction of turn mainly due to the difference in induced drag on each wing.
a momentary yawing motion opposite to the turn due to an incorrect differential aileron movement.
the tendency of an aeroplane to yaw in the opposite direction of turn mainly due to the difference in aileron form drag.
the tendency of an aeroplane to yaw in the same direction of turn due to the different wing speeds.

variant.question: How is adverse yaw compensated for during entry into and roll out from a turn?

options.text: Differential aileron deflection.
Horn balanced controls.
Servo tabs.
Anti-balanced rudder control.

variant.question: How is adverse yaw compensated for during entry into and roll out from a turn?

options.text: Differential aileron deflection.
Horn-balanced controls.
Servo tabs.
Anti-balanced rudder control.

variant.question: When using aileron-rudder coupling to prevent adverse yaw, when the aircraft is rolled to the right, the left aileron is deflected

options.text: down, the right aileron is deflected up, and the rudder is automatically deflected to the right.
up, the right aileron is deflected down, and the rudder is automatically deflected to the right.
down, the right aileron is deflected up, and the rudder is automatically deflected to the left.
up, the right aileron is deflected down, and the rudder is automatically deflected to the left.

variant.question: When using aileron-rudder coupling to prevent adverse yaw, when the aircraft is rolled to the right, the left aileron is deflected...

options.text: down, the right aileron is deflected up, and the rudder is automatically deflected to the right.
up, the right aileron is deflected down, and the rudder is automatically deflected to the right.
up, the right aileron is deflected down, and the rudder is automatically deflected to the left.
down, the right aileron is deflected up, and the rudder is automatically deflected to the left.

variant.question: If the nose of an aeroplane yaws left, this causes:

options.text: a roll to the left.
a roll to the right.
a decrease in relative airspeed on the right wing.
an increase in lift on the left wing.

variant.question: Which of the following phenomena is counteracted by the use of differential ailerons?

options.text: Adverse yaw.
Aileron reversal.
Turn co-ordination.
Sensitivity to spiral dive.

variant.question: The aircraft yaws to the left. This occurs because:

options.text: You roll to the right.
There is increased lift in the right wing.
You roll to the left.
You press the right pedal.

variant.question: Adverse aileron yaw will cause the nose to yaw out of the turn because:

options.text: There is less drag on the down-going wing
There is more drag on the down-going wing
There is more drag on the up-going aileron
There is less drag on the down-going aileron

variant.question: The use of ailerons induces adverse (aileron) yaw. This occurs as a result of the...

options.text: up-going wing producing more drag than the down-going wing.
up-going wing being subjected to more aerodynamic damping than the down-going wing.
down-going wing producing more drag than the up-going wing.
up-going wing having a higher rate of roll when compared to the down-going wing.

variant.question: To counter adverse yaw, an aircraft has aileron / rudder coupling. In a right turn, which of the following statements is true?

options.text: Left aileron goes down, right aileron goes up, and the rudder automatically moves to the right.
Left aileron goes up, right aileron goes down, and the rudder automatically moves to the right.
Left aileron goes up, right aileron goes down, rudder automatically moves to the left.
Left aileron goes down, right aileron goes up, and the rudder automatically moves to the left.

variant.question: During the take-off roll, when the pilot raises the tail in a tail wheeled, clockwise (seen from pilot's perspective) rotating propeller driven aeroplane , a strong left yaw is generated, forcing the pilot to apply almost full right rudder to keep the aeroplane on the centreline. Before the tail is raised, the left yaw is caused by (I) and after the tail is raised the left yaw is caused by (II).

options.text: (I) spiralling slipstream; (II) gyroscopic precession
(I) gyroscopic precession; (II) asymmetric blade effect
(I) spiralling slipstream; (II) asymmetric blade effect
(I) torque reaction; (II) asymmetric blade effect

variant.question: In asymmetric flight, yawing towards the live engine gives a sideslip force on the fuselage side...

options.text: behind the CG and opposite to the rudder force.
forward of the CG and opposite to the rudder force.
forward of the CG and similar to the rudder force.
behind the CG and similar to the rudder force.
